Text: Praise the LORD. Sing to the LORD a new song, His praise in the assembly of the saints.
Context: The psalm opens with a call to praise aimed at the faithful community, invoking joy and celebration.

Text: Let Israel rejoice in their Maker; let the children of Zion be glad in their King.
Context: Continuing the theme of praise, the focus is on Israel finding joy in God as their creator and king.

Text: Let them praise His name with dancing and make music to Him with tambourine and lyre.
Context: The expression of praise is through physical movement and music, indicating a high level of joy and celebration.

Text: For the LORD takes pleasure in His people; He adorns the humble with salvation.
Context: This verse highlights God's love for His people and His special care for the humble, attributing positive emotions to God.

Text: Let the saints exult in glory; let them sing for joy on their beds.
Context: This verse suggests a continuous state of praise that extends to private moments, indicating joy is a constant in the life of the believers.

Text: May the high praises of God be in their mouths, and a double-edged sword in their hands,
Context: This verse introduces an element of might and resolve, with the word of God portrayed as a weapon for the faithful.

Text: to execute vengeance on the nations and punishment on the peoples,
Context: Here the focus shifts to the idea of God's judgement and justice through His people, reflecting a more assertive role for the faithful.

Text: to bind their kings with shackles, their nobles with chains of iron,
Context: The notion of justice continues, with the prediction or prescription of restraints on the leaders of opposing nations.

Text: to carry out the sentence written against themâ€”this is the glory of all His saints. Praise the LORD.
Context: The final verse concludes with a reaffirmation of the God-given role of the faithful in enacting justice, ultimately tying it back to praise and honour.
